ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course gave me a deep and comprehensive understanding of Northern Irish history and how the legacies of its conflict continue to impact life in the region today. I also gained a broader sense of what it means to understand and remember history through using a variety of media types (history books, documentaries, news articles, and poetry) and by speaking directly with historians, activists, and scholars from Northern Ireland who joined our classes at Professor Weirs request.

I broadened my understanding of the conflict in Northern Ireland.
Learned about more nuanced approaches to conflict and solutions.
I learned so much about the politics of Northern Ireland, as well as European politics in general. I truly feel like I learned a massive amount of information.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The strengths of this course were many, so here are some of the biggest ones. Professor Weir is incredibly knowledgeable and well-connected and uses her experience to make the content as accessible as possible. She packed an incredible amount of information into the syllabus without it ever seeming overwhelming. Getting the chance to speak directly with other experts on the subject was wonderful, but Professor Weir also did a great job of encouraging students to share their own thoughts and analysis through presentations and discussion. 

The only thing that I would improve about this class is that I would have liked a few more opportunities to speak with my classmates in smaller groups and get to know them that way (always a struggle on Zoom!).

Strengths: Professor Weir is amazing. I loved the format of the class, with weekly guest speakers and classmate-led summaries of course material. The guest speakers were all so interesting. Weaknesses: Because we had guest speakers every class, we didn't have as much time for class discussion. I wished I could have spoken to/gotten to know my classmates more, and also heard more of Prof. Weir's insights. Prof. Weir didn't give us much feedback on our weekly reflections.

A strength is listening and learning from guest speakers who were directly involved in Northern Ireland's conflicts. A weakness is that the grading is arbitraryonly ~a quarter of grades were uploaded by the end of the semester to canvas, so it's hard to gauge what exactly the professor is looking for.

Strengths: Professor Weir, class discussions, guest speakers

Weaknesses: student presentations (usually very long and not as engaging as lecture)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having weekly assignments rather than a few large papers was helpful for me in staying consistently engaged with the course without feeling overwhelmed by looming deadlines. It was also a treat to Zoom with experts residing in Northern Ireland, which I dont think would have been as possible in a non-virtual format.

Each class a student would give a presentation and then the guest speaker would answer student questions. It would've been useful if the professor contextualized the point of that week's readings and tied together the readings, speaker presentation, and guest speaker's bio at some point during class.
It succeeded extremely well, incorporating Zoom to bring in many guests.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This seminar is a great political science or history class for anyone who wants to go in-depth about a particular region with the help of a really wise professor. Its also accessible for students who may not have taken upper-level history or political science seminars - this was my first history class but I wasnt overwhelmed!

Yes! Class assignments are weekly reflections and not papers  which is a pro or a con depending on what you want to get from the course. I would have felt a lot more satisfied leaving the class having completed at least one paper. Either way, the course was amazing. I loved Prof. Weir and the guest speakers and feel like I know so much more about the Troubles. I do wish I'd gotten to engage with the coursework in a more meaningful way, though.

Yes. Learning about Northern Ireland gives one a platform to learn about the complications that are involved in sectarian violence. No conflict is as simple as they are made out to be, and there are fewer conflicts in the world that demonstrate the complex nature of violence as well as Northern Ireland does.
Conflict in Northern Ireland isn't heavily discussed in other classes, so if this is a topic of interest, then you should take the course
Yes, to anyone who is genuinely interested in learning about Northern Ireland.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

extras.title:
GLBL 289 01/PLSC 431 01/HIST 245J 01
        War and Peace in N Ireland
